Another downside to badly wrapping your headphones (or as musicians call it "bad cable etiquette" ;p) is that it severely decreases the lifespan of the cable because the wires inside of audio cables are (generally) twisted together. Usually when haphazardly storing away your cable by quickly rolling it up you actually end up applying extra tension to the wires inside the cable, decreasing their lifespan. The alternative to the figure 8 is to simply coil your cable in a single loop while respecting the natural state of the wires inside. Hold one end of the cable in one hand, as you make the first coil you can feel how the cable resists twisting one direction (usually resulting in the part of the cable you've coiled already starting to deform/twist), while twisting in the other direction "agrees" with the tensions already present in the cable. Make your coil, respect the natural flow of the cable, and also make sure you coil on alternating sides. So the first coil goes on the outside of the hand holding the end, the next on the inside etc.

Ok maybe just do the figure 8 instead of deciphering my description. Either way, your headphones and other audio cables will last you many more years if you get into this habit :) most of my headphones as well as my guitar cables that got lots of abuse when I still gigged pre-covid survived for multiple years regardless of the price I bought them at, including a pair of £5 headphones I've been using as a reference when mixing the past 5 years :)

Cooking science life-hack: Those "garlic/onion/fish odor removal" bars are just little blocks of stainless steel (the sulfur compounds that make the odors bind to the metals, removing them from your skin). The knife you cut the garlic up with is almost certainly steel, as well. So instead of buying an extra product that takes up counter space, you can just use your fingers (CAREFULLY) instead of a rag to clean your knife and get the smell off your hands at the same time.

If you've cooked scrambled eggs and there's some egg stuck to the bottom of the pan, fill the pan almost to the brim with warm water (ideally around 40C/100F) add a heaped teaspoon of biological washing powder, and leave for half an hour or so. You'll find you need to scrub a whole lot less to clean the pan. The washing powder contains enzymes which break down proteins, fats and carbohydrates, and those enzymes are effective against cooked egg. The enzymes only function at certain temperatures, which is why you need a full pan of warm water - it keeps the enzymes at the right temperature for longer than a half-full pan.

LIFE hack: When swimming if you get tired and don't feel you have the energy to get back to safety, get a comfortable lungful of air and relax sort of in a standing position with your arms floating to your side. Most people will naturally float with the top of the head at the surface of the water. The rest of us will float only a few inches below the surface. When you need air, bring your arms down to your side as if you are a bird flapping your wings. This will propel your head above water so you can get another lungful. You can keep yourself from drowning, not tire yourself out, and get closer to safety by doing this.

An easier way to tell if lenses are polarized is to hold up two of them (or two pairs of glasses) and turn them at right angles two each other. Polarized lenses in this arrangement will let no light through (i.e., you will only see opaque black where they overlap). Non-polarized lenses will be no darker at right angles than when they are in another alignment.

Physics Girl -- Can't open a glass bottle with a metal cap? Put it under warm to hot water for a few minutes. Metal expands faster than glass when heated. OR, you can use the friction of your hand to heat the metal by rubbing the cap in a twisting motion. After a bit of effort, it should pop open.

Some containers are under vacuum when you try to open them (e.g., food in a left-over container). For these, sometimes, opening the lid is in effect fighting against outside air pressure. Consider squeezing the container to equalize the pressures, and the lid should open far more easily.

You can also wrap them the way audio techs wrap cords (mic cords in particular, which have two wires crisscrossing around a central wire...kinks from twisted cables mess up the balance resulting in sound quality issues).  After making a normal loop, you invert your hand for the next loop so that the free end of the cord is on the inside of the loop rather than the outside of the loop, and you just keep alternating as you make loops. Basically the first loop twists the cord one way and the second twists it the other so that the two cancel out when when the ends are pulled apart. This works really well with very long cords, and as you're coilling up long cords you can feel the cord not fighting you as you coil it compared to doing it normally.

I have a hypothetical situation. Imagine an ordinary star out in space. The universe is expanding and there are two observers. One observer is on the red shift side of the star, the other is on the blue shift side of the star. In the center of the star, two identical photons are released at the same time. Both have a wavelength of 500 nm. Which means, based on this formula, E=hc/λ, the energy of each photon is 2.4796 eV. One photon moves toward the observer on the red shift side of the star, the other photon moves toward the observer on the blue shift side of the star. When the blueshift photon reaches the blueshift observer, it has a wavelength of 400 nm which means that it has 3.0995 eV of energy. When the redshift photon reaches the redshift observer, it has a wavelength of 600 nm, which means that it has 2.0663 eV of energy.
So, the blueshift photon has more energy. Where did it come from?
The redshift photon has less energy. Where did the energy go?
Also, from the photons' point of view, aren't they still 500 nm?

With the car life hack, some fluid mechanics to the rescue perhaps?

So here's what I've been observing. I'm not sure if it's true so I would appreciate people helping me to test it out. Anyway I realise that a car tends to cool faster if you opened windows which are diagonally opposite (front left and rear right, or vice versa), as compared to opening all the windows. See, in opening all the windows, the air flow is turbulent, and not much air that comes into the car is actively forcing more air out of the car. However, my theory is if you were to open only diagonally opposite windows, whatever air that comes in from the front window immediately pushes air out of the rear opposite window(while driving, of course). The air that's pushed out in turn sucks more air in from the front thanks to the negative hydrostatic pressure created.

Were you to open both windows on the same side it would be akin to blowing over a cup - only a tiny fraction of the air you blew over the cup's mouth actually goes into the cup and forces air in the cup out. The same would happen if you opened all windows in a car.

Again, would love to see someone test this theory and confirm (or debunk) it.

problem with the idea of removing sticker residue with a solvent (doesn't matter if its oil, ethanol, isopropylalcohol or another nonpolar solvent) is that you basically just spread the glue all over the surface. If you try to clean everything up with water (because you don't want an oily bottle...), a part of the glue will just stay there because the now extra sticky oil won't mix with the water - and then all of the surface is sticky in an annoying way.
make sure you remove the solvent + the solved glue completely by using an emulsifier; for example just plain soap, and then washing everything away with water. An emulsifier is a molecule with a polar and a nonpolar side; so it is able to "combine" hydrophylic and lipophylic substances (like water and oil).

1. The trick to test if glasses are polarized by using a cell phone screen only works with LCD screens. If a screen uses OLED technology, a polarized filter has basically little or no impact. (LCD technology is based on polarization -- the screen alters the polarization of the light coming from the screen's backlight so that the portions of the image that are intended to be visible aren't blocked by a polarized filter at the front of the screen. OLED screens are self-illuminating and require no polarizing filters to produce an image.)

2. The figure 8 is a variant of the over/under technique that professionals use when winding cables. The basic idea is that wrapping a cable/rope/hose this way automatically removes the twist created by wrapping in the first place (one loop creates, the next loop removes), rather than adding a new twist with each loop like you get with the way most people wrap their cables. The over/under technique is a life hack that everyone should know since it works for everything that is cable-like. You'll never have a knotted, twisted vacuum cord again!

I don't know about lame, but the next time you go to microwave something, don't put it directly in the center of the rotating dish inside the microwave. The cold spots in microwaves are caused by an interference pattern in the wave field inside the microwave. If you put the food directly in the center, it may spend more time in a "dead zone" of the interference pattern.  It is best to maximize the distance that the food travels inside the microwave. Therefore, you should put it as far towards the edge of the spinning disk as possible. Check out The Engineer Guy's video on how a microwave works if you don't believe me.

If the glasses are rotationally polarized, like 'RealD' glasses, they won't change as you turn them. If the polarization is the same direction in both lenses AND it's rotationally polarized, it will be a real trick to figure it out on the fly. If they are opposite polerization, like realD, one direction should block light passing through the opposite polerization. The best bet, therefore, is to grab a set of realD glasses and see if the sunglasses darken with either side of the realD glasses held up to them. 😎

You could use these hacks at face value OR you could tweak them up a notch:
- On the car-door - Don't just touch the (painted) outside of the car - paint insulates, remember? - instead touch the bare metal on the latch where the door locks. Way more effective.
- Use butter (or margarine) instead of oil or WD40 or acetone. Butter is an oil-in-water suspension, so while the oil dissolves the glue, the water prevents it from re-sticking to the surface. Try it. Seriously.
- Some smartphones use circularly polarized light (as do 3D glasses in cinemas) - while sunglasses need plane-polarization to cut glare from reflections. Hence the "LCD turning dark" test can sometimes yield false-negatives!

Especially during dry tropical winters, working with adhesive scotch tape becomes difficult due to the static electricity that builds up in the snap-straightened strip of the tape which is normally rolled up. If you try to join small picecs of papers together, the adhesive strip of the scotch tape will often attract the pieces before you make an intentional contact with them, thus displacing your careful arrangement of the paper fragments. An easy solution I use to avoid this is to touch with my small finger the non-adhesive surface of the snap-stretched scotch tape strip before I bring it near the intended pieces of papers I want to join. Didn't get it? Don't worry! You might not understand what I'm saying if you do not meet the following peculiar sets of criteria: 1) living in tropics; 2) doing paper crafts using adhesives (not origami); 3) using scotch tape as adhesive (or even recognizing one if available at your locality)

Adding water to tea mix and find yourself staring down at a cup full of foam? Turn your faucet down until the stream is clear. The turbulence in a faucet running full blast catches air as the water enters your drink and the drink mix combined with the water retains that air because of its improved surface tension. When your tap has clear water coming out it's what's called a laminar flow; the water molecules are all flowing in the same direction and not slamming off of everything. This causes a smooth stream that doesn't catch air. (This probably seems like a no brainer to most of the people watching these videos but it's surprising how many people never stopped to think about it)
